title: 110_hr5513
content: The Act is titled the "Stop Adolescent Smoking Without Excessive Bureaucracy Act of 2008" and aims to strengthen state laws regarding tobacco product sales to individuals under the age of 18. For fiscal year 2010 and subsequent years, the Secretary can grant funds under section 1921 if the state has a law prohibiting the sale of tobacco products to individuals under 18. It is also illegal for individuals under 18 to purchase, receive, or possess tobacco products in public places. Law enforcement must take action if a minor is found violating these laws. Any person distributing tobacco products at retail must notify employees about laws prohibiting sales to individuals under 18 and ensure compliance. Employers are not in violation if minors possess tobacco products in public places. Employers who rely on valid age proof or implement a program can avoid penalties for violating the prohibition on selling tobacco to minors. States with delayed legislative sessions have a later deadline for compliance. Funding agreements for grants must align with state goals for noncompliance starting from the first applicable fiscal year. The funding agreement for a grant under section 1921 requires states to establish goals for reducing the rate of retailer violations of tobacco laws through annual inspections. The rate of violations must decrease each fiscal year, with a target of 10 percent from fiscal year 2020 onwards. States must also enforce the law to receive the grant. The funding agreement for a grant under section 1921 requires states to enforce tobacco laws to reduce availability to individuals under 18. States must conduct annual inspections and submit reports on enforcement activities and success in meeting goals. The funding agreement for a grant under section 1921 mandates states to enforce tobacco laws to limit access to individuals under 18. States can involve individuals under 18 in compliance testing with parental consent and direct supervision. States must also certify the use of settlement proceeds for enforcement activities. Before granting funds under section 1921, the Secretary must determine if a State has complied with specified requirements. If noncompliance is found, the Secretary can reduce the State's allotment for that fiscal year. Compliance includes using settlement funds for health programs, tobacco control, cessation activities, or economic development in tobacco regions. The Secretary can reduce a State's allotment under section 1921 if noncompliance with specified requirements is found, starting at 10% for fiscal year 2010 and increasing annually. Compliance involves using settlement funds for health programs, tobacco control, cessation activities, or economic development in tobacco regions. The Secretary can reduce a State's allotment under section 1921 by 10% annually for noncompliance with requirements. Assistance is provided for implementing State laws, with model legislative language developed and technical guidance offered. The term 'first applicable fiscal year' is defined for different states. The effective date for the amendment is specified. The provisions of section 1926 of the Public Health Service Act apply to fiscal years preceding the first applicable fiscal year. The term "first applicable fiscal year" is defined in subsection (g) of section 1926. SEC. 3. PUBLIC DISCLOSURE OF INGREDIENTS. The Federal Cigarette Labeling and Advertising Act is amended to make ingredient information accessible to the public online within 48 hours of submission to the Secretary.
